title: Castanet
text:
The wonder fabric of the 1960s was nylon knit; it was easy to wash, resisted wrinkling and therefore required little or no ironing and traveled easily. It was not beloved by all consumers, however, so the Ja-eL line sometimes used other fabrics.  Although not as easy to clean, wool jersey draped well and was easy to care for and therefore was used for some production.  

<I>Castanet<I> was marketed in six different colorways, but was discontinued with the demise of Ja-el production.  <I>Minaret<I> and <I>Firebird<I>, renamed <I>Ballet Ruse<I> (on exhibit in the hall), were printed on a woven rather than a knit ground cloth and were included in the Larsen interiors line during the late 1960 and into the 70s.
description: Jersey fashion print.  Stylized floral pattern.  Largest motif 10\"x 11\". 32\" vertical pattern repeat.Printed on a plain weave Jersey fashion print.  Stylized floral pattern on orange background.  Largest motif 10\' x 11\'. 32\' vertical pattern repeat. (orange/black)
